   Radiology Studies:
   [**11-3**] High resolution chest CT:
   1. Recent changes over four days documented by conventional chest
   radiographs
   indicate that at least some of the reticular and ground-glass
   abnormalities in
   the lungs, which have worsened since [**10-29**] are pulmonary edema.
   The
   progression of the same abnormalities between [**10-9**] and [**10-29**] could
   be due to some component of interstitial lung disease, which was
   clearly
   present on the earliest examination.
   2. Persistent pulmonary arterial hypertension and global cardiomegaly.
   Severe
   coronary atherosclerotic calcification. Aortic valvular calcification
   of
   uncertain significance.
   3. Large thyroid cysts or nodules. Ultrasound examination recommended
   if not
   already obtained.
   For subsequent evaluation of the progression of pulmonary edema or
   interstitial lung disease, conventional radiograph should be employed
   as a
   first step.
   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 79 yo M with PMH DM2, interstitial lung disease,
   diastolic CHF, CAD s/p NSTEMI with recent diagnosis of unresectable
   cholangiocarcinoma s/p CBD excision, cholecystectomy, lymph node bx,
   PTC placement and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, with no further
   surgical management, transferred to MICU for hypoxia, feeling well but
   remaining hypoxic.
   .
   # Hypoxia
 Patient continued to be on non-rebreather for the better
   part of yesterday. This morning he was transitioned to a high-flow mask
   and is impoved on that. Read of high resolution chest CT yesterday was
   suspicious for pulmonary edema in setting of underlying interstitial
   lung disease, however overall picture is more consistent with an
   atypical infection or PCP in setting of his interstitial lung disease.
   Will not purse further diuresis given he overall appears euvolemic and
   had hypotension after diuresis yesterday.  We are continuing treatment
   for PCP in the setting of his elevated LDH and long-term steroid use
   and CT that could be consistent with this.  Less likely is lymphangitic
   spread of carcinoma.- Patient just completed 7 days of levofloxacin
   (day 1 = [**2138-10-27**])
   - Ordered induced sputum culture for PCP stain as well, given that the
   only negative PCP stain is from a sample that was contaminated.
   Currently patient appears too tenuous to bronch at present.
   - Initiate steroid treatment for PCP yesterday, which will also treat
   his intersitial lung disease, if this is playing role. Plan will be for
   prednisone 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] for 5 days (day 1 = [**11-3**]), 40 mg daily for 5 days,
   then 20 mg for 11 days. Initiated [**Month/Year (2) **] IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]) for PCP
   treatment as well.
   - Initiated vancomycin and zosyn today for hospital acquired PNA (day 1
   = [**11-4**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed
   - Continue attempt to wean O2, to keep sat >92%
   - Will hold off PFTs as not likely to be helpful in setting of acute
   decompensation.
   - ICU fellow [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 955**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 90**] discussed case with patient
s outpatient
   pulmonologist, Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5568**]. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5568**] reported that the patient had
   presented several years ago and had diffuse changes on CT (ground
   glass, fibrosis). The patient was initially treated with high dose
   steroids, then quickly tapered down to maintance dose (2.5-10 mg per
   reports).  A bronchosocpy was never completed per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5568**]
s report.
   This would likely be helpful for additional work up, but patient
   remains too tenuous to bronch at present.
   .
   # Fever, leukocytosis: Resolved from yesterday, when there had been
   concern for infection in setting of low grade temp and leukocytosis.
   Continuing to monitor for infection (possible sources including urinary
   given foley, lung given hypoxia, and GI given percutaneous drain).
   - Will follow up culture data, antibiotics as noted above should also
   cover gram negative pathogens from GU/GI tract.
   .
   # Hypotension
 Yesterday had transient hypotension (80
s), which was
   asymptomatic. This episode was likely secondary to his diruesis after
   the lasix he received. His borderline low BP remains likely
   multifactorial with differential diagnosis including intravascularly
   depleted vs adrenal insufficiency in setting of long term steroid use
   vs diabetic autonomic dysfunction. Yesterday concern was for possibly
   brewing sepsis, but resolved today. Will consider tolerating if
   mentating, making urine, asymptomatic and MAP >55-60.
   - Goal SBP >100
   - AM cortisol was 24.5 on [**11-2**], on steroids [**Hospital1 **] for above reasons.
   - Holding lisinopril given recent creatinine bump.
   - If possible, once more stable, will consider addition of low dose
   metoprolol given recent NSTEMI if tolerated by bp
   .
   # Cholangio CA, biliary stricture - Curative surgery not possible,
   reconstruction with roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy performed in [**Month (only) 705**]
   [**2138**].
   - Follow-up as outpatient with oncology
will try to reach patient
   primary oncologist today to further discuss his prognosis to help
   further discuss goals of care and how aggressively to further work up
   and treat his pulmonary process.
   - Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 511**]
s team will see patient today to help guide
   recommendations for drain, appreciate assistance. Tube is in place
   mainly for imaging purposes and will be taken out in future.
   .
   # CAD/NSTEMI - NSTEMI at OSH with troponin peak at 0.76 on [**10-27**],
   trending down since, prior ECG changes with diffuse precordial T wave
   inversion, now improved.
   - Cardiology had been following, recommended medical management (ASA,
   low-dose B-Blocker if BP tolerates, Statin, Plavix, holding ACEi given
   ARF, hypotension)
   .
   # Acute diastolic CHF - Potentially NSTEMI precipitated or infection,
   now likely clinically euvolemic. BNP drawn with AM labs.
   - Will discuss possible trial of diuresis today, however creatinine did
   bump from 1.1 to 1.3 overnight.
   - CXR overall unchanged.
   - Last echo as noted above.
   - Attempting to see if possible to concentrate medications to lessen
   IVF load.
   .
   # ARF- This morning creatinine 1.3, which is a bump from yesterday
   1.1. Previously had bumpted to 1.4, likely secondary to diuresis
   - Will continue to follow trend.
   .
   # Heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan - Consider ultrasound to further
   characterize, once more stable or as outpatient.
   - TSH 0.51 on [**11-1**]
   .
   # Anemia: HCT dipped down today to 25. Over last weeks to month, has
   been 26-29. Iron Studies indicative of Anemia of Chronic Disease given
   advanced ca; no evidence of acute bleeding.
   - Folate, TSH, B-12 all within normal limits.
   - Will check PM HCT to ensure it is stable.
   .
   # DM2: FSBG have been running high since last night (300
s-400
   Suspect secondary to increased steroid dose, also possibly related to
   infection. Glargine was increased last night to 40 units.
   - Given ability to improve control while patient remains in ICU, will
   initiated insulin gtt.
   .
   #. FEN - Cardiac, diabetic diet. Will replete electrolytes as needed.
   .
   #. Communication - Wife, [**Name (NI) 2856**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5547**], and son [**Name (NI) 2667**] [**Name (NI) **]
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5548**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Diabetic, cardiac
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin gtt.
   Lines:
   PIVs x2
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  Heparin SQ
   Stress ulcer:  On PPI for hx GERD as well.
   VAP:  N/A
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code currently, patient still thinking over
   options
will try to re-address with wife today, oncologist.
   Disposition: ICU until respiratory status improved.
Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was transferred to the ICU for hypoxia and remains hypoxic despite being on a high-flow mask. His recent high-resolution chest CT showed worsening reticular and ground-glass abnormalities, pulmonary arterial hypertension, and global cardiomegaly. He also has severe coronary atherosclerotic calcification and aortic valvular calcification of uncertain significance. The patient's current condition is stable, and he is alert and awake. He has dry crackles throughout all lung fields, especially at the bases. His blood pressure is borderline low, and he has an elevated JVP. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hematocrit, and lactate levels. He has been treated for suspected PCP infection with steroids and IV antibiotics. The patient's fever and leukocytosis have resolved. He continues to be monitored for infection sources, including urinary, lung, and GI tract. His creatinine level has increased from 1.1 to 1.3 overnight, potentially due to diuresis. The patient's anemia is likely due to anemia of chronic disease, and his diabetes mellitus type 2 is poorly controlled. His cardiac, diabetic diet is being followed, and insulin gtt has been initiated

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

- The patient has worsening reticular and ground-glass abnormalities on a high-resolution CT scan, along with pulmonary arterial hypertension and global cardiomegaly. Severe coronary atherosclerotic calcification is also noted.
- The patient experienced hypotension in the morning, which was treated with a bolus of fluid.
- The patient has been started on treatment for PCP (Pneumocystis pneumonia) and prednisone.
- One sputum sample was negative for PCP.
- The patient's glucose levels are elevated, possibly due to the prednisone treatment. Insulin has been increased to manage this.
- The patient's surgeon has been contacted for a plan regarding percutaneous tube placement.
- No known drug allergies are reported.
- The patient received antibiotics (vancomycin, piperacillin, and SMX/TMP) at different times.
- The patient is currently on heparin sodium for prophylaxis.
- Other medications include changes to medical and family history, review of systems, and flow sheet data.

1. Worsening respiratory distress due to the worsening ground-glass abnormalities and pulmonary arterial hypertension.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was transferred to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for hypoxia and has been on a non-rebreather mask for the better part of yesterday. The high-resolution chest CT showed worsening reticular and ground-glass abnormalities, pulmonary arterial hypertension, and global cardiomegaly. There are also severe coronary atherosclerotic calcifications and aortic valvular calcification of uncertain significance.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38.1°C, heart rate of 78 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 121/57 mmHg to 135/69 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission, except for the recent development of fever and leukocytosis, which has since resolved.

The patient has been treated for presumed Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) with prednisone and IV Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX). He also received vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for hospital-acquired pneumonia. The patient's recent laboratory results show elevated white blood

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 79-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and previous non-ST elevation myocardial infarction.
- He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and is currently on high-flow nasal cannula oxygen.
- The patient has a recent diagnosis of unresectable cholangiocarcinoma following a cholecystectomy, lymph node biopsy, percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC), and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy.
- His current vital signs include a temperature of 36.5°C, heart rate of 74 beats per minute, blood pressure of 111/50 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on 100% face mask.
- Physical examination reveals dry crackles throughout all lung fields, especially at the bases, and a percutaneous drain in place.
- Laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin level, normal platelet count, and abnormal liver function tests.
- The patient is being treated empirically for Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) due to long-term steroid use and CT findings.
- He is also receiving antibiotics for suspected hospital-acquired pneumonia.
- The patient's anemia is being investigated, with transfusion planned

The patient has undergone several surgeries including CBD excision, cholecystectomy, lymph node biopsy, percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) placement, and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy. 

The patient was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and feeling well but remaining hypoxic. He is currently on 100% oxygen support. The CT chest shows suspicious findings for pulmonary edema, but there are also atypical infection or Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) considerations. 

The patient has been treated empirically for PCP with prednisone and Bactrim. Vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam have been continued for hospital-acquired pneumonia. Nebulizer therapy is being provided as needed, and attempts are being made to wean off oxygen. 

The patient's anemia is of unclear etiology, possibly due to blood loss, hemolysis, or chemotherapy-related marrow suppression. Further investigations are planned to determine the cause.

   PTC placement and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, with no further

   his breathing has improved. Prior CT chest suspicious for pulmonary
   edema in setting of ILD, but clinical picture is consistent with an
   atypical infection or PCP. [**Name10 (NameIs) 1204**] lack of improvement to treatment for
   hospital-acquired pneumonia and PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) 5604**] pulse dose steroids
   yesterday to treat possible exacerbation of his interstitial lung
   disease. Will continue to monitor over next 24 hrs, as would expect
   some improvement in oxygen need if steroids are helping. No evidence of
   fluid overload on exam, continues to be negative balance for I/O

   [**11-3**]), 40 mg daily for 5 days, then 20 mg for 11 days.  Yesterday
   started methylprednisolone 250 mg IV TID for three days.
   - Bactrim IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]), today is day 4, was changed to PO
   yesterday to limit fluid loads.

   = [**11-3**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed

s respiratory status is too tenuous

s transfusion. Etiology still

Summary:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and is currently on high-flow mask oxygen. The patient's breathing difficulty may be worsening, reflecting oxygenation issues. His respiratory status has been improving but remains tenuous. The patient is on multiple medications including antibiotics, steroids, and other supportive treatments.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Exacerbation of interstitial lung disease: The patient's worsening respiratory status and difficulty oxygenating may indicate an exacerbation of his pre-existing interstitial lung disease.
2. Hospital-acquired pneumonia: The patient is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, indicating concern for hospital-acquired pneumonia. This could be due to his prolonged ICU stay and immunocompromised state.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and a recent NSTEMI. His current hypotension and fluid overload may suggest cardiac involvement.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia remains unresolved, and further investigation is needed to determine the etiology.
5. Hemolysis: There is suspicion of hemolysis, possibly related to Bactrim use or cancer-related causes. Monitoring stool guaiac and hemolysis labs is essential.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and has been experiencing persistent and slightly worsening hypoxia. The patient's current medications include insulin, methylprednisolone, heparin sodium, metoprolol, simvastatin, senna, Tylenol, and others.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient has worsening consolidation on chest x-ray and is at risk for aspiration due to his inability to protect his airway.
2. Pulmonary fibrosis exacerbation: The patient's symptoms may be consistent with an exacerbation of his underlying interstitial lung disease.
3. Hospital-acquired pneumonia: The patient is at risk for developing hospital-acquired pneumonia due to prolonged ICU stay and exposure to healthcare settings.
4. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient is at risk for DVT due to immobility and central venous catheter use.
5. Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA): The patient's diabetes management needs close monitoring to prevent DKA.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of CAD and diastolic CHF puts him at risk for cardiac complications such as myocardial ischemia or infarction.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia etiology remains unclear and requires further investigation.
8. Hemolysis: The patient's bloody stool or emesis could indicate hemolysis, possibly related to bactrim use or cancer-related.
9. Hypotension: The patient's recent hypotension may be related to diuresis or medication effects.
10. Biliary strictures: The patient's history of cholangiocarcinoma and biliary reconstruction requires ongoing monitoring for complications related to biliary strictures.

Please note that these potential complications are based on the information provided in the progress note.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 61 bpm, blood pressure of 113/60 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95% on nasal cannula with supplemental oxygen. The patient is awake and alert, speaking in full sentences. Laboratory results show a white blood cell count within normal range, slightly low hematocrit, and normal platelet count. Renal function tests indicate a creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL. Other lab values, including electrolytes, liver enzymes, cardiac markers, and coagulation profile, are within normal limits.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 79-year-old male with a history of interstitial lung disease (ILD), diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF), recent non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), unresectable cholangiocarcinoma, and admitted with hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient's main concerns include respiratory failure, CHF/CAD, elevated creatinine, anemia, diabetes mellitus, and cholangiocarcinoma. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has been experiencing worsening hypoxia this week and is likely suffering from ILD, possibly idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) or nonspecific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP). The recent respiratory failure may indicate a progression of the underlying lung disease. Continuous monitoring and oxygen support will be necessary to manage the patient's respiratory status.
2. CHF/CAD: The patient has diastolic CHF and a history of NSTEMI. These conditions increase the risk of cardiac complications such as heart attack or heart failure exacerbation. The patient is already on aspirin, statin, and Plavix for CAD management, and metoprolol for heart rate control. Gentle diuresis will be attempted today, and ACE inhibitors may be considered once the creatinine levels improve.
3. Elevated Creatinine: The patient's baseline creatinine levels are elevated, indicating potential kidney dysfunction. Further investigation into the cause of kidney

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of interstitial lung disease (ILD), diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF), recent non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), unresectable cholangiocarcinoma, admitted with hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient's chief complaint is dyspnea, which has improved. However, he is now reporting worse dyspnea when lying down. His oxygen saturation (SaO2) is in the mid-80s on nasal cannula (NC) and non-rebreather mask (NRB). The chest X-ray from November 7th shows worsening consolidation or aspiration. The urine legionella antigen test returned negative. The patient has been receiving multiple antibiotics and other medications, including heparin sodium, ASA, MVP, pantoprazole, Zocor, metoprolol, senna, Plavix, and Zosyn.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.9°C (98.4°F), heart rate of 61 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 113/60 to 138/62 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95% on NC. The patient is on sinus rhythm. Fluid balance shows a total input of 1,890 mL and output of 1,360 mL, resulting in a balance of 530 mL

   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 79 yo M with PMH DM2, interstitial lung disease,
   diastolic CHF, CAD s/p NSTEMI with recent diagnosis of unresectable
   cholangiocarcinoma s/p CBD excision, cholecystectomy, lymph node bx,
   PTC placement and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, with no further
   surgical management, transferred to MICU for hypoxia, with persistent
   and slightly worsening hypoxia.
   Hypoxia: Acute episode of extreme hypxia (O2 sat 50-60s) and
   unrespiveness, resolved with improving o2 sats. The pulse dose steroids
   have no appreciably changed his oxygen requirement or breathing.
   Overall picture still most consistent with exacerbation of his
   pulmonary fibrosis, less likely atypical infection or CHF
   - Patient s/p 7 days of levofloxacin (day 1 = [**2138-10-27**])
   - PCP negative in sputum x1, but poor sputum samples
   - Continue 3 weeks of empiric PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) **]:
   - On [**11-3**], started steroids. [**11-6**], started 3 days of methylprednisolone
   250 mg IV QID. Starting 60 mg PO prednisone daily [**11-9**].
   - Bactrim PO (day 1 = [**11-3**]), today is day 7
   - s/p vancomycin and zosyn for hospital acquired PNA (day 1 = [**11-3**]),
   (day [**8-18**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed
   - Continue attempt to wean O2, to keep sat >90%
   - Too tenuous to bronch at present.
   - PRN 0.5mg IV morphine for worsening dypsnea to make patient more
   comfortable.
   - Do not suspect CHF, but will aim to get patient negative today to
   ensure this is not playing role.
   - Inhaled mucomist for tx of fibrosis,
   - Ddimer elevated, will hold of on initiating hep gtt for now, but will
   consider if worsens.
   - Discussed aspiration precautions with patient, nursing.
   Anemia: Stable, mildly improved today. received 1 unit PRBCs last week.
   Etiology still remains unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 59**] reported bloody stool or emesis.
   Maybe hemolysis, bactrim related marrow [**Last Name (LF) 5587**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be cancer
   related.
   - Monitoring stool guaiac (negative thus far)
   - Hemolysis labs have not been consistent with hemolysis
   - transfuse 1 unt today for anemia and hypoxia
   Hypotension:  Resolved. Hypotension in past has been in setting of
   diuresis. AM cortisol was 24.5 on [**11-2**], on steroids [**Hospital1 **] for above
   reasons.
   - Holding lisinopril and BB given borderline pressures.
   Cholangio CA, biliary stricture:  No changes in management. Curative
   surgery not possible, reconstruction with roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy
   performed in [**2138-9-12**].

   of care and how aggressively to further work up and treat his pulmonary

s team tube is in place mainly for imaging purposes

   Acute diastolic CHF: Potentially NSTEMI precipitated or infection, now

Summary:
Summary:
- The patient is a 79-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma.
- He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and has had multiple episodes of acute decompensation with oxygen saturation levels in the 50-60s.
- The patient received Lasix for diuresis, Mucomyst for interstitial lung disease, and a d-dimer test for possible pulmonary embolism.
- He experienced an episode of acute hypoxemia, which resolved as his oxygen saturation improved. An EKG showed STD in infero-lateral leads, and enzymes were sent for evaluation.
- The patient has been on various medications including Piperacillin/Tazobactam, Vancomycin, Bactrim, Furosemide, and Heparin.
- His vital signs are stable, but he remains hypoxic with an oxygen saturation of 89%.
- The patient has a history of NSTEMI, cholangiocarcinoma, biliary stricture, and reconstruction with roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy.
- He has been on steroids for his pulmonary fibrosis and is currently on prednisone.
- The patient's anemia is stable and mildly improved with a transfusion of one unit of packed red blood cells.
- His hypotension has resolved,

Summary:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and a recent diagnosis of unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and has been experiencing persistent and slightly worsening hypoxia. The patient has been on high-dose steroids for his pulmonary fibrosis and is currently receiving methylprednisolone 250 mg IV QID. He also has anemia that is stable and mildly improved today, and he received one unit of packed red blood cells this week. The etiology of the anemia remains unclear.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia is persistent and slightly worsening, which may indicate a worsening of his underlying pulmonary fibrosis or the development of a new respiratory condition.
2. Infection: The patient has been on antibiotics for hospital-acquired pneumonia and has been given empiric treatment for Pneumocystis pneumonia. Monitoring for signs of infection and adjusting treatment accordingly is important.
3. Hemolysis: The patient has reported bloody stool or emesis, which raises the possibility of hemolysis. Further investigation is needed to confirm or rule out this diagnosis.
4. Cardiac issues: The patient has a history of NSTEMI and diastolic congestive heart failure. Monitoring his cardiac status and managing any complications related to

Summary:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. The patient presented to the ICU with hypoxia and has been treated with pulse dose steroids for exacerbation of pulmonary fibrosis. The patient's condition has not improved significantly, and there are concerns about potential complications such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), or heart failure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pneumonia: The patient's decreased oxygen saturation and worsening respiratory status may indicate a possible pneumonia. Close monitoring of vital signs, chest X-ray, and sputum cultures will be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and guide appropriate antibiotic therapy.

2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): Given the patient's underlying pulmonary fibrosis and recent steroid treatment, there is a risk of developing ARDS. Continuous monitoring of oxygenation and respiratory parameters is crucial to identify any signs of worsening respiratory distress.

3. Heart Failure: The patient's history of diastolic congestive heart failure increases the risk of heart failure exacerbation. Close monitoring of fluid balance, cardiac enzymes, and echocardiography may be needed to assess cardiac function and manage accordingly.

4. Hemolysis: The patient's anemia and bloody stool or emesis raise the suspicion of hemolysis. Further evaluation of hemoglobin levels, blood smear

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of interstitial lung disease (ILD) on prednisone, diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF), recent non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), unresectable cholangiocarcinoma, and admitted with hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient's condition has been gradually worsening this week. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has hypoxemic respiratory failure and a poorly characterized ILD, with concerns for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) or nonspecific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP). The patient's respiratory status is likely to continue being a concern.
2. CHF/CAD: The patient has diastolic CHF and a recent NSTEMI, indicating possible underlying coronary artery disease (CAD). This increases the risk of further cardiac complications.
3. Elevated Creatinine: The patient has an elevated creatinine level, which suggests impaired renal function. This can be associated with medications, underlying conditions, or other factors.
4. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, indicating anemia. Further evaluation and management are required.
5. Diabetes Mellitus: The patient has diabetes mellitus, which requires monitoring and appropriate management.
6. Cholangiocarcinoma: The patient has unresectable cholangiocarcinoma, which may require further treatment planning and management.

- The patient is a 79-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and a recent diagnosis of unresectable cholangiocarcinoma.
- The patient was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and has been experiencing worsening hypoxia despite receiving pulse dose steroids.

- Physical examination shows dry rales throughout all lung fields and a flat jugular venous pressure.

- The patient's hypotension has resolved, and his blood pressure is being closely monitored.
- The patient has a history of NSTEMI and requires medical management for CAD.
- The patient's cholangiocarcinoma and biliary stricture are being managed conservatively.
- The patient has a heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan and requires further evaluation

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and recent diagnosis of unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with worsening hypoxia presumably from his pulmonary fibrosis. The patient's hypoxia has not improved with pulse dose steroids for interstitial pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), antibiotics for hospital-acquired pneumonia, and treatment for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP). The overall picture still most consistent with exacerbation of his pulmonary fibrosis, less likely atypical infection or CHF.

The patient has been on several medications, including levofloxacin for hospital-acquired pneumonia, Bactrim for PCP prophylaxis, vancomycin and zosyn for hospital-acquired pneumonia, nebulizer treatment, and inhaled mucomist for fibrosis. The patient's D-dimer levels are elevated, but no heparin has been given due to the risks outweighing the benefits. Aspirin, low-dose beta-blocker, statin, and Plavix have been recommended for CAD/NSTEMI management. The patient is also being monitored for anemia and hypotension.

The patient's cardiac status includes a recent NSTEMI with troponin peak at 0.76 on [**10-27**], and an ECG showing diffuse precordial T-wave inversion, now improved. The patient's diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF) is potentially NSTEMI precipitated or infection-related, now likely clinically euvolemic. No right ventricular (RV) pathology has been observed in recent echocardiograms.

Other assessments include heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan, which may require further characterization with an ultrasound as an outpatient. The patient's diabetes mellitus type 2 management involves switching to NPH and regular insulin due to poor oral intake. The patient's diet consists of a cardiac, diabetic diet, and electrolytes will be replenished as needed. Currently, the patient is on NRB (nonrebreather) due to episodes of dyspnea with desats to 70s, resolved without intervention. The patient's family has been informed about his declining status, and he has made a do-not-resuscitate/do-not-intubate (DNR/DNI) decision.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Exacerbation of pulmonary fibrosis: The patient's worsening hypoxia is most consistent with an exacerbation of his pulmonary fibrosis. This can lead to further respiratory distress and potential respiratory failure if not managed appropriately.
2. Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP): Despite receiving antibiotics, the patient's respiratory status has not improved. There is a risk of developing HAP due to his prolonged ICU stay and immunocompromised state.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of CAD/NSTEMI, and his cardiac status needs to be closely monitored for any signs of worsening heart failure or arrhythmias.
4. Thromboembolic events: The patient is at risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) due to prolonged immobilization and underlying risk factors.
5. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's blood pressure fluctuations may indicate potential hemodynamic instability, which requires close monitoring and appropriate intervention.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia needs to be closely monitored, and further investigation into the cause is necessary.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: Although the patient's stool guaiac has been negative thus far, there is a possibility of gastrointestinal bleeding, especially considering his use of NSAIDs and anticoagulation therapy.

Overall, the patient's condition remains critical, and close monitoring and aggressive management of his respiratory status, cardiac function, thromboembolic risk, hemodynamic stability, anemia, and gastrointestinal bleeding are essential to prevent further complications and optimize his outcomes.

He was admitted to the ICU with worsening hypoxia presumably due to pulmonary fibrosis. The patient has not improved with various treatments including pulse dose steroids, antibiotics for hospital-acquired pneumonia, and treatment for Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). His clinical prognosis is grim, and the decision has been made to focus on comfort care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's worsening hypoxia and dependence on the non-rebreather mask suggest a high risk of respiratory failure.
2. Infection: The patient has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics, but there has been no clinical improvement, indicating a possible ongoing infection.
3. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's blood pressure has been fluctuating, indicating potential hemodynamic instability.
4. Anemia: The patient has received one unit of packed red blood cells due to stable anemia, which may be related to chronic kidney disease or cancer-related bone marrow suppression.
5. Thromboembolic events: The patient is at risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) due to immobilization and malignancy.
6. Diabetic complications: The patient has diabetes mellitus type 2

   Patient is a very pleasant 79 year old male with interstitial lung

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of interstitial lung disease, diabetes mellitus, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He has been experiencing progressive deterioration of his respiratory status despite treatment for pneumonia, diuresis, and pulse-dose steroids. His worsening respiratory status is believed to be due to an acute flare-up resulting in decompensation from his pulmonary fibrosis. The focus now is on comfort measures. The patient is receiving morphine boluses every 3-5 minutes to alleviate dyspnea and will have the oxygen nasal cannula and NRB removed according to his wishes. The patient has a Do Not Resuscitate/Do Not Intubate (DNR/DNI) status.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is worsening, and he may experience further respiratory failure if the oxygen supply is removed.
2. Hypoxemia: The patient's SpO2 level is currently at 82%, indicating a decrease in oxygen saturation. Removing the oxygen supply could lead to further hypoxemia.
3. Increased pain and discomfort: Administering higher doses of morphine may cause increased sedation and potential respiratory depression.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of diastolic congestive heart failure, and his tachycardia may worsen if he experiences significant discomfort or distress.
5.
